elements.content: The one-dimensional (1-D) coordination polymers [Cu(2,4‘-bpy)4SO4]·6H2O (1), [Cu(4-phpyr)4SO4]·5H2O (2), [Cu(2,4‘-bpy)4SiF6]·4.5 H2O (3), and [Cu(4-phpyr)4SiF6]·4.5H2O (4) (2,4‘-bpy = 2,4‘-bipyridine, 4-phpyr = 4-phenylpyridine) have been prepared in aqueous solution and characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structures of 1−4 manifest zigzag 1-D chains constructed from interdigitated “X-shaped” CuL4 2+ cations and the relevant counteranions while entraining hydrogen-bonded supramolecular water substructures that serve to connect the 1-D coordination polymer subunits into pseudo three-dimensional (3-D) structures. In 1, 1-D aqueous tapes comprised of water molecule tetramers and individual water molecules are evident. Discrete zero-dimensional (0-D) water clusters are observed in 2, while discrete water molecule chains are manifested in 3 and 4. The markedly different morphologies of the respective aqueous substructures within this family of coordination polymers are dictated by the nature of the ligand as well as the counterion. Thermal properties of 1 and 3 also are discussed.

Thermal properties of 1 and 3 also are discussed.

elements.content: A family of one-dimensional coordination polymers, [Cu(L)4X]·nH2O (L = 2,4‘-bipyridine (2,4‘-bpy), 4-phenylpyridine (4-phpyr); X = SO4 2-, SiF6 2-; n = 4.5, 5, or 6), has been prepared and structurally characterized. These possess hydrogen-bonded supramolecular water aggregations with markedly different morphologies, dictated by both the ligands and the counterions.

elements.content: There has been much contemporary interest in one-dimensional (1-D) hydrogen-bonded aqueous tapes due to their role in water and ion transport through cell membranes, for example, through the pores in the channel protein aquaporin-1. In addition, numerous theoretical and experimental structural studies have been carried out on discrete hydrogen-bonded water clusters, including tetramers, hexamers, octamers, decamers, and a bulk-model 280-molecule unit, to further understand the “anomalous” properties of water. A recent approach to the isolation of supramolecular water aggregations has involved their stabilization within coordination polymer matrices via the ligation of water molecules to metal centers or by hydrogen bonding to counteranions and ancillary ligands. Because of the unique “container” environments imparted by various coordination polymer chains, layers, and networks, a host of supramolecular water molecule chains, rings, tapes, and layers have been generated. Many of these hydrogen-bonded water molecule aggregations mirror those previously found in hydrated organic crystals. It has been revealed that the novelty of many of these recently reported aqueous motifs has been overstated. Nevertheless, deliberate modification of enclathrated aqueous substructures by judicious adjustment of a particular coordination polymeric system is less common.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been much contemporary interest in one-dimensional (1-D) hydrogen-bonded aqueous tapes due to their role in water and ion transport through cell membranes, for example, through the pores in the channel protein aquaporin-1. In addition, numerous theoretical and experimental structural studies have been carried out on discrete hydrogen-bonded water clusters, including tetramers, hexamers, octamers, decamers, and a bulk-model 280-molecule unit, to further understand the "anomalous" properties of water. A recent approach to the isolation of supramolecular water aggregations has involved their stabilization within coordination polymer matrices via the ligation of water molecules to metal centers or by hydrogen bonding to counteranions and ancillary ligands. Because of the unique "container" environments imparted by various coordination polymer chains, layers, and networks, a host of supramolecular water molecule chains, rings, tapes, and layers have been generated. Many of these hydrogen-bonded water molecule aggregations mirror those previously found in hydrated organic crystals. It has been revealed that the novelty of many of these recently reported aqueous motifs has been overstated. Nevertheless, deliberate modification of enclathrated aqueous substructures by judicious adjustment of a particular coordination polymeric system is less common.

elements.content: In this paper, we report a family of four hydrated copper coordination polymers of formulation [Cu(L)4X]·nH2O (L = 2,4‘-bipyridine (2,4‘-bpy), 4-phenylpyridine (4-phpyr); X = SO4 2-, SiF6 2-; n = 4.5, 5, or 6), [Cu(2,4‘-bpy)4SO4]·6H2O (1), [Cu(4-phpyr)4SO4]·5H2O (2), [Cu(2,4‘-bpy)4SiF6]·4.5 H2O (3), and [Cu(4-phpyr)4SiF6]·4.5H2O (4), that exhibit differing supramolecular water molecule motifs. As seen in a prior report, 2,4‘-bpy can bind to a metal cation at its 4‘-terminus while providing a structure-directing hydrogen-bonding acceptance site at its unligated 2-position nitrogen atom. With its substitution of a C−H subunit for the 2-position nitrogen atom in 2,4‘-bpy, 4-phpyr lacks this traditional hydrogen-bonding acceptance locus, thus modifying the observed arrangement of unligated water molecules. In addition, we have explored the effect on the water molecule aggregations due to the number and disposition of hydrogen-bonding acceptor atoms within the counteranionic subunit in this system. Therefore, via adjustment of the ancillary ligands and counteranions, a modicum of “crystal engineering” of the supramolecular water molecule substructure within a family of related coordination polymers was achieved.

elements.content: General Considerations. All starting materials were obtained commercially (CuSO4·5H2O (>99%) and 4-phenylpyridine from Aldrich, Cu(BF4)2·xH2O from Alfa Aesar, and 2,4‘-bipyridine from TCI America). Water was deionized above 3 MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One spectrophotometer using pure solid samples. The rapid loss of water molecules of crystallization from 1−4 precluded elemental analysis of fully hydrated samples.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Considerations. All starting materials were obtained commercially (CuSO4⋅5H2O (>99%) and 4-phenylpyridine from Aldrich, Cu(BF4)2⋅xH2O from Alfa Aesar, and 2,4‘-bipyridine from TCI America). Water was deionized above 3 MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One spectrophotometer using pure solid samples. The rapid loss of water molecules of crystallization from 1-4 precluded elemental analysis of fully hydrated samples.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(2,4‘-bpy) 4 SO 4 ] · 6H 2 O (1). CuSO4·5H2O (41.6 mg, 0.167 mmol), 2,4‘-bipyridine (104.1 mg, 0.667 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:4:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and then was allowed to cool to 25 °C. Long transparent blue crystalline blocks grew over the course of one week. A total of 92.8 mg (62.2% yield based on Cu) of 1 was collected after filtration and washing with water and acetone. Calcd for 1 with retention of five water molecules of crystallization:  54.94% C, 4.84 H, 12.81 N, Found 55.00% C, 4.49 H, 12.68 N.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(4-phpyr) 4 SO 4 ] · 5H 2 O (2). CuSO4·5H2O (41.6 mg, 0.167 mmol), 4-phenylpyridine (103.5 mg, 0.667 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:4:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and then was allowed to cool in air to 25 °C, resulting in a blue solution with brown oily droplets (presumably undissolved 4-phenylpyridine) adhering to the sides of the tube. Transparent blue crystalline blocks grew over the course of two months out of the oily droplets, admixed with a light blue amorphous powder. Unfortunately, we were unable to manually separate enough pure 2 for elemental and thermal analysis.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(2,4‘-bpy) 4 SiF 6 ]·4.5H 2 O (3). Cu(BF4)2·xH2O (54.5 mg, 0.167 mmol if x = 5), 2,4‘-bipyridine (139 mg, 0.890 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:5.3:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and was allowed to cool in air to 25 °C. Crystalline purple rods were noticed after one week and grew to large size after one month. A total of 128 mg (85.0% yield based on Cu) of 3 was collected after filtration and washing with water and acetone. Calcd for fully dehydrated 3:  57.86% C, 3.88 H, 13.49 N, Found 59.03% C, 3.79 H, 13.23 N.

elements.content: X-ray Diffraction and Structure Solution. Reflection data for 1−4 were acquired on a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD X-ray diffractometer at 173 K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data sets were processed via SAINT and subjected to Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections using SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms, with the exception of oxygen atoms in waters of crystallization in the structure of 2, were refined anisotropically. The distended thermal ellipsoids among several carbon atoms in nonligated pyridyl rings within the structure of 1 are attributable to a slight amount of conformational disorder due to rotation about the ring-joining C−C single bonds. Attempts at modeling this disorder were unsuccessful. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms belonging to all water molecules in 1 and 2 were found via Fourier difference maps and then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. The crystallographically disordered water molecules in 3 and 4, and the pyridyl ring disorder in 3, were modeled using partial occupancies. No hydrogen atoms could be found for the water molecules in the Fourier difference maps for 3, nor on one of the water molecules of crystallization for 4. Neutral atom scattering factors were taken from Cromer and Waber, and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from those of Creagh and McAuley. Crystallographic details for 1−4 are given in Table .

elements.content: Synthesis and Dehydration Behavior. Blue crystals of 1 and 2 were easily synthesized by flame sealing an aqueous mixture of CuSO4·5H2O with four molar equivalents of the appropriate ligand into a borosilicate glass tube, heating to 120 °C for 1 h, and allowing the sealed tube to stand at room temperature for an extended period. Purple crystals of 3 and 4 were prepared by a similar method, using hydrated Cu(BF4)2 instead. Leaching of silicon from glass tubes by aqueous BF4 - to form hexafluorosilicate anions in situ has been observed previously. Compounds 3 and 4 were first prepared via a similar method by combination of CuCl2·2H2O, Na2SiF6, and the appropriate pyridine. However, these products were contaminated with a large quantity of flocculent green solid, rendering separation difficult. Crystals of 1−4 develop significant opacity very soon after drying, presumably due to the effluence of cocrystallized water molecules. The crystals are also not stable in distilled water, efflorescing into flaky powders within 1 day. Long-term storage of all species is possible only in their respective mother liquors.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Dehydration Behavior. Blue crystals of 1 and 2 were easily synthesized by flame sealing an aqueous mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O with four molar equivalents of the appropriate ligand into a borosilicate glass tube, heating to 120 °C for 1 h, and allowing the sealed tube to stand at room temperature for an extended period. Purple crystals of 3 and 4 were prepared by a similar method, using hydrated Cu(BF4)2 instead. Leaching of silicon from glass tubes by aqueous BF4 - to form hexafluorosilicate anions in situ has been observed previously. Compounds 3 and 4 were first prepared via a similar method by combination of CuCl2⋅2H2O, Na2SiF6, and the appropriate pyridine. However, these products were contaminated with a large quantity of flocculent green solid, rendering separation difficult. Crystals of 1-4 develop significant opacity very soon after drying, presumably due to the effluence of cocrystallized water molecules. The crystals are also not stable in distilled water, efflorescing into flaky powders within 1 day. Long-term storage of all species is possible only in their respective mother liquors.

elements.content: Infrared Spectra. The infrared spectra of 1−4 are consistent with their chemical formulas. The very strong and broad features at approximately 3400 cm-1 in the spectra of all four species arise from O−H stretching frequencies in the waters of crystallization. Aromatic ring stretching and puckering mechanisms are attributed to the medium intensity bands in the regions of 1500−1650 cm-1 and 600−750 cm-1, respectively. For 1 and 2, S−O stretching within the ligated sulfate ions causes strong bands at 1120 and 1080 cm-1. As expected, these latter bands are absent in 3 and 4, with new intense spectral features observed in the region of 750−800 cm-1, ascribed to Si−F stretching modes.

elements.content: Coordination Polymer Structure. 1−4 all crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̄, with asymmetric units consisting of two crystallographically distinct half-occupancy Cu atoms on inversion centers, four 2,4‘-bpy (1, 3) or 4-phpyr ligands (2, 4), one sulfate (1, 2) or hexafluorosilicate (3, 4) anion, and varying numbers of water molecules of crystallization. As a representative example, the asymmetric unit of 1 is shown in Figure .

As a representative example, the asymmetric unit of 1 is shown in Figure .

elements.content: Extension of the structures of 1 and 2 reveals infinite neutral 1-D [CuL4SO4] n (L = 2,4‘-bpy, 4-phpyr) coordination polymer chains running along the crystal a-axis, produced by the linkage of “X-shaped” [CuL4]2+ cations through trans-disposed sulfate counterions. (Figure for 1; 2 presents an extremely similar structure.) Given the observed bond lengths in 1 and 2 (Table ) the coordination environments about all of the d9 Cu(II) ions are best considered as “4+2” [CuN4O2] Jahn-Teller distorted octahedra, which corner-share vertices with [SO4] tetrahedra to form the 1-D coordination polymer chains. Bond angles about the Cu atoms in 1 and 2 were wholly consistent with the observed distorted octahedral coordination (Table S1, Supporting Information).

Bond angles about the Cu atoms in 1 and 2 were wholly consistent with the observed distorted octahedral coordination (Table S1, Supporting Information).

As seen in Figure , the 4‘-nitrogen termini of the bipyridine moieties in 1 are ligated, while the 2-position nitrogen atoms remain unbound to metal atoms, presumably due to steric inaccessibility. In both cases, two trans-disposed 2,4‘-bpy ligands bound to Cu1 interdigitate between 2,4‘-bpy ligands bound to both nearest neighbor Cu2 atoms, sterically inducing larger inter-ring torsion angles within the Cu2-bound ligands (16.5° and 20.4° as compared to 13.3° and 13.5° for the ligands bound to Cu1). In both 1 and 2, the sulfate oxygen atoms O3 and O4 are not coordinated to Cu, projecting directly into the oblong ∼12.5 × ∼6.4 Å channels (as defined by through-space Cu−Cu distances) between neighboring 1-D coordination polymer chains. These channels run along the (111) crystal direction and contain supramolecular aggregations of water molecules of crystallization (vide infra), which serve to connect the 1-D coordination polymer chains into the pseudo 3-D crystal structure via hydrogen bonding (Figure for 1). As illustrated by the rapid degradation of 1 and 2 in the absence of their respective mother liquors, these supramolecular interactions are critical to the structural integrity of these compounds.

elements.content: The structures of 3 and 4 are similar to 1 and 2 with some marked differences. Each Cu atom is coordinated by four ligands and two trans-oriented hexafluorosilicate anions to form Jahn-Teller distorted [CuN4F2] coordination octahedra, similar to those displayed in the methane-absorbing coordination polymer [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)2SiF6]. Each [CuN4F2] octahedron is connected to its neighbor by corner-sharing vertices through cis positions on a [SiF6] octahedron, thus forming the 1-D coordination polymer chains (Figure , for 3; 4 presents an extremely similar structure). This arrangement contrasts with that observed in [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)2SiF6], where adjacent Cu ions conjoin through trans fluorine atoms on a single hexafluorosilicate moiety. Bond distance and angle data for 3 and 4 are consistent with distorted octahedral coordination about copper and are given in Table and Table S2 (Supporting Information), respectively.

The tighter bond angles within the octahedral hexafluorosilicate anions, as compared to tetrahedral sulfate anions, do not permit equal bond lengths from Cu to the anionic moieties in 3 and 4. For example, in 3, bridging F1 fluorine atoms cannot orient themselves directly toward neighboring Cu2 cations, causing the Cu1−F1 distance to be ∼0.22 Å longer than the respective Cu2−F2 bond distance. The larger size of SiF6 2- relative to SO4 2- permits a longer Cu−Cu through-space distance of 6.54 Å, thus causing the zigzag undulations to be less pronounced in 3 and 4 as compared to those in 1 and 2. This structural relaxation allows the ligands to adopt more extreme twisted conformations than in 1 and 2, with inter-ring torsion angles ranging between 5.7° and 27.8°. As in 1 and 2, oblong channels containing aggregations of water molecules of crystallization course down the (111) crystal direction. However, the channels in 3 and 4 are slightly increased in size (∼13.0 × ∼6.5 Å) relative to those in 1 and 2, perhaps influencing the morphology of the supramolecular water molecule substructures along with the different number and disposition of hydrogen-bonding acceptors within the hexafluorosilicate counteranion (vide infra). As is the case with 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are unstable in the absence of their respective mother liquors, once again reflecting the importance of the ligated anion-to-water molecule supramolecular interactions on the structural integrity of this family of compounds. The supramolecular aggregation of neighboring 1-D polymeric [CuL4X] chains in 1−4 is further enhanced by π−π stacking between pendant aromatic rings belonging to 2,4‘-bpy or 4-phpyr ligands in adjacent chains. The π−π stacking distances in the pyridyl derivatives 1 and 3 (∼3.7 Å) are closer by 0.1 Å compared to those in 2 and 4.

elements.content: Water Molecule Aggregation Morphologies in 1 − 4. As seen in Figure , the water molecules of crystallization within 1 form discrete 1-D aqueous tapes via hydrogen bonding, which are themselves hydrogen bonded to the coordination polymer matrix. These 1-D supramolecular water tapes are comprised of two crystallographically distinct hydrogen-bonded tetrameric water clusters, tet-a (green) and tet-b (orange), linked through hydrogen bonding via single water molecules (magenta), thus forming an infrequently observed T4(0)A1 tape motif. The water tetramer tet-b is further decorated by two single water molecules (cyan). The O···O distances within tet-a are 2.80 and 2.94 Å, while those within tet-b are somewhat longer, with values of 2.95 and 3.00 Å. All O···O hydrogen-bonding interactions are comparable or slightly longer than those observed in pure water (2.854 Å). Hydrogen-bonding contact distances within 1 are listed in Table .

Fortunately, the hydrogen atom positions in 1 could be ascertained from Fourier difference maps, permitting a detailed understanding of the hydrogen-bonding patterns within each tetramer, between the tetramers, and between the tetramers and the coordination polymer chains. As seen in Figure , the hydrogen-bonding patterns about each water tetramer in 1 are similar yet with important differences. In both tetramers, every water hydrogen atom serves as a hydrogen-bond donor. Both tetramers are capped by two individual water molecules via hydrogen bonding. However, the individual water molecules marked by O2W and O2WA, which donate hydrogen bonds to O1W and O1WA in tet-a, do not themselves accept any hydrogen bonds. This is in contrast to the individual water molecules marked by O5W and O5WA, which donate hydrogen bonds to tet-b water molecules O4W and O4WA and further accept hydrogen bonds from adjacent tet-a tetramer water molecules O1W and O1WA. This latter interaction serves to connect the individual water tetramers into the “infinite” 1-D aqueous tapes observed in 1.

elements.content: The tetramers of type tet-b then connect the 1-D water tape to the [Cu(2,4‘-bpy)4SO4] n coordination polymer backbone via hydrogen bonding from H4WA to N4, the 2-position nitrogen atom of a 2,4‘-bpy unit bound to Cu1. The tetramers are further conjoined indirectly to each other, and directly to the coordination polymer backbone, through the intervening sulfate counterions via hydrogen bonding from tet-a (at H3WB) and tet-b (at H6WB) to oxygen atoms O3 and O4, respectively. Both of these hydrogen-bonding interactions serve to connect the 1-D coordination polymer chains into the pseudo 3-D structure of 1. Taking the sulfate oxygen atoms and pyridyl nitrogen atoms into account, a 1-D hydrogen-bonded tape of type U1 incorporating conjoined R4 rings and D3- and D5-type discrete chains10 can be reckoned. Detailed data for all hydrogen-bonding interactions within 1 is listed in Table S3, Supporting Information.

elements.content: The intervening sulfate anions do not permit the water clusters in 1 to be considered true cyclic water hexamers. Nevertheless, the aggregation of pairs of individual water molecules with the water tetramers can loosely be described as forming incipient hexamers. The individual water molecules hydrogen bonded to tet-a lie 2.80 Å above and below the tetramer plane, resulting in a very distorted “chair” conformation for this incipient hexamer. In contrast, the individual water molecules hydrogen bonded to tet-b are positioned much closer to the planar tetramer (1.03 Å above and below), causing this incipient hexamer to adopt a “ring-chair” conformation. Previous theoretical studies5 indicate that several different water hexamer conformations are easily accessible due to their energetic similarities. Recently, discrete water hexamers in both planar and chair conformations have been observed simultaneously within the framework of a Co(II) cyclohexanehexacarboxylate 3-D coordination polymer.

elements.content: While the coordination polymer backbone within 2 is very similar to that in 1, the lack of a hydrogen-bonding acceptor atom in the 4-phpyr ligand provokes a notable difference in the supramolecular morphology of the waters of crystallization in 2, which is displayed in Figure . As in 1, water tetramers (green) are observed, but these no longer form “infinite” tapes. Each is hydrogen bonded to four neighboring individual water molecules (cyan and magenta), thus forming an incipient isolated 0-D water octamer. These tetramer-decorating water molecules connect to the coordination polymer backbone by donating hydrogen bonds to neighboring sulfate ions. However, the incipent octamers themselves fail to form a 1-D water tape due to their inability to provide hydrogen-bonding interactions to other water molecules. An infinite 1-D water tape of type U1 in 2 can be invoked if sulfate oxygen atoms are taken into account. In contrast to 1, discrete water dimers are in evidence, bridging two adjacent sulfate ions in neighboring coordination polymer chains through hydrogen bonding. It is proposed that the replacement of the 2-position nitrogen atom in 2,4‘-bpy in 1 with an aromatic C−H unit in the 4-phpyr ligand in 2 prevents the formation of a second type of water tetramer and also an “infinite” water tape, due to the inability of 4-phpyr to provide the necessary hydrogen-bonding point of contact. Hydrogen-bonding contact distance information for 2 is given in Table .

elements.content: Utilizing the hexafluorosilicate anion, which possesses more hydrogen-bonding points of contact than does the sulfate ion, resulted in different supramolecular water molecule morphologies in 3 and 4. In contrast to 1 and 2, no obvious cyclic water clusters can be identified in either structure. However, discrete serpentine chains of consisting of nine water molecules each (D9 motif10) are observed in both 3 and 4 (see Figures and , respectively). All of the water molecule positions in 3 are half-occupied due to crystallographic disorder with the exception of that marked by oxygen atom O1. It is likely that this disorder is instigated by the crystallographic disorder in the orientation of a single type of pendant pyridyl ring, whose carbon atom (C17) and nitrogen atom (N4) positions can be interconverted by inter-ring C−C σ-bond rotation during self-assembly, thereby permitting hydrogen-bonding acceptance at two different disordered nitrogen positions. The discrete water chain in 4 is comprised of fully occupied positions with the exception of the central water molecule (O5), which is disordered equally over two symmetry-related positions. In contrast to the sulfate-bearing coordination polymers 1 and 2, 1-D tape extended motifs are not present in 3 and 4 even if the anion hydrogen-bonding acceptor atoms are considered.

elements.content: The closest O···O contact distances between the neighboring water molecule oligomers in 3 and 4 (4.87 and 3.45 Å, respectively) are both well outside the accepted range of hydrogen bonding. Thus, as in 2, the water molecule aggregations in both 3 and 4 fail to directly connect into an “infinite” 1-D tape. Nevertheless, the disordered water oligomers serve to connect neighboring 1-D [CuL4SiF6] n coordination polymer chains into their full pseudo 3-D crystal structures via hydrogen bonding to the hexafluorosilicate anions in both cases, and in 3, to the disordered nitrogen atom positions N4 and N4A in a single type of 2,4‘-bpy moiety. The discrete water molecule chain motif in 4 is noticeably similar to that in 3 but with some subtle differences due to the lack of hydrogen-bonding points of contact in the 4-phpyr ligands. For instance, the O3···F5 hydrogen-bonding contact in 4 is 0.25 Å closer than the corresponding distance in 3, due to the absence of any competing supramolecular interactions of similar strength. Hydrogen-bonding contact distances within 3 and 4 are given in Table .

elements.content: Thermal Behavior. The visible degradation of crystals of 1−4 when not stored in their respective mother liquors is indicative of the rapid loss of water from the structure. Room temperature release of water was previously observed in the dehydration of [Cu(4,4‘-bpy)2SiF6]·4H2O. Water release from the crystal structures of 1 and 3 was corroborated by thermogravimetric analysis. 1 expelled all of its water molecules of crystallization (15.1% observed, 12.1% predicted) by 170 °C in two steps, beginning immediately upon the commencement of heating (Figure S1, Supporting Information). Loss of most of the 2,4‘-bpy ligands (62.7% observed, 70.0% predicted for complete ligand removal) occurred in two steps beginning at 170 °C and ending at ∼400 °C. The final mass at 600 °C (79.0% observed, 82.1% predicted) was roughly consistent with a CuSO4 remnant. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) trace for 3 (Figure S2, Supporting Information) indicated that elimination of all water molecules of crystallization had likely occurred during the short interval between isolation and the thermogravimetric analysis (∼10 min), as no mass loss whatsoever was observed until ∼170 °C. Loss of all 2,4‘-bpy ligands (83.8% obsd, 75.2% predicted based on dehydrated 3) proceeded in two steps between 170 and ∼400 °C, virtually identical to that observed in the thermal degradation of 1. The higher than expected mass loss could potentially arise from the concomitant expulsion of some SiF4 upon thermal decomposition. The total mass loss for 3 is consistent with a remnant mixture of CuF2 and CuSiF6.

elements.content: A family of four related 1-D coordination polymers of formulation [CuL4X]·n H2O (L = 2,4‘-bpy, 4-phpyr; X = SO4 2-, SiF6 2-; n = 4.5, 5, or 6) have been prepared and structurally characterized via single crystal X-ray diffraction, which revealed the presence of different supramolecular unligated water molecule aggregations in all cases. The dimensionalities and morphologies of these water molecule aggregations were demonstrated to be critically dependent on the nature of the organic ligand and counterion. The differing patterns of water molecule aggregation in 1 and 2 versus 3 and 4 can be assigned to the change in the number of unligated hydrogen-bonding acceptor atoms within the anionic subunits. The differences between the pairs 1 and 2, and 3 and 4, can be ascribed to the presence or the absence of a hydrogen-bonding acceptance site within the organic moiety. It is plausible that a synergistic effect between hydrogen bonding of water molecules to the anionic and organic subunits, respectively, directs structure formation during self-assembly of these coordination polymers. The chemical and thermal behaviors of these materials also indicate the significant stability-inducing role of hydrogen-bonded water molecule aggregations in this class of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A family of four related 1-D coordination polymers of formulation [CuL4X]⋅n H2O (L = 2,4‘-bpy, 4-phpyr; X = SO4 2-, SiF6 2-; n = 4.5, 5, or 6) have been prepared and structurally characterized via single crystal X-ray diffraction, which revealed the presence of different supramolecular unligated water molecule aggregations in all cases. The dimensionalities and morphologies of these water molecule aggregations were demonstrated to be critically dependent on the nature of the organic ligand and counterion. The differing patterns of water molecule aggregation in 1 and 2 versus 3 and 4 can be assigned to the change in the number of unligated hydrogen-bonding acceptor atoms within the anionic subunits. The differences between the pairs 1 and 2, and 3 and 4, can be ascribed to the presence or the absence of a hydrogen-bonding acceptance site within the organic moiety. It is plausible that a synergistic effect between hydrogen bonding of water molecules to the anionic and organic subunits, respectively, directs structure formation during self-assembly of these coordination polymers. The chemical and thermal behaviors of these materials also indicate the significant stability-inducing role of hydrogen-bonded water molecule aggregations in this class of coordination polymers.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Cu(2,4‘-bpy) 4 SO 4 ] · 6H 2 O (1). CuSO4·5H2O (41.6 mg, 0.167 mmol), 2,4‘-bipyridine (104.1 mg, 0.667 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:4:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and then was allowed to cool to 25 °C. Long transparent blue crystalline blocks grew over the course of one week. A total of 92.8 mg (62.2% yield based on Cu) of 1 was collected after filtration and washing with water and acetone. Calcd for 1 with retention of five water molecules of crystallization:  54.94% C, 4.84 H, 12.81 N, Found 55.00% C, 4.49 H, 12.68 N.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-phpyr) 4 SO 4 ] · 5H 2 O (2). CuSO4·5H2O (41.6 mg, 0.167 mmol), 4-phenylpyridine (103.5 mg, 0.667 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:4:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and then was allowed to cool in air to 25 °C, resulting in a blue solution with brown oily droplets (presumably undissolved 4-phenylpyridine) adhering to the sides of the tube. Transparent blue crystalline blocks grew over the course of two months out of the oily droplets, admixed with a light blue amorphous powder. Unfortunately, we were unable to manually separate enough pure 2 for elemental and thermal analysis.

Synthesis of [Cu(2,4‘-bpy) 4 SiF 6 ]·4.5H 2 O (3). Cu(BF4)2·xH2O (54.5 mg, 0.167 mmol if x = 5), 2,4‘-bipyridine (139 mg, 0.890 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:5.3:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and was allowed to cool in air to 25 °C. Crystalline purple rods were noticed after one week and grew to large size after one month. A total of 128 mg (85.0% yield based on Cu) of 3 was collected after filtration and washing with water and acetone. Calcd for fully dehydrated 3:  57.86% C, 3.88 H, 13.49 N, Found 59.03% C, 3.79 H, 13.23 N.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-phpyr) 4 SiF 6 ] · 4.5H 2 O (4). Cu(BF4)2·xH2O (54.5 mg, 0.167 mmol if x = 5), 4-phenylpyridine (103.5 mg, 0.667 mmol), and 6.00 mL of deionized water (1:4:2000 molar ratio) were mixed in a borosilicate glass tube. The tube was flame sealed and heated to 120 °C for 1 h and was allowed to cool in air to 25 °C, resulting in a blue solution with brown oily droplets adhering to the sides of the tubes. Long transparent purple crystalline rods grew over the course of two months out of the oily droplets. A total of 96.9 mg (63.7% yield based on Cu) of 4 was collected after filtration and washing with water and acetone. Calcd for 4 with retention of three water molecules of crystallization:  60.02% C, 4.81 H, 6.36 N, Found 60.90% C, 4.07 H, 6.40 N.
